sect1.sect2:
Introduction to qemu
qemu is a full virtualization solution for Linux on x86 hardware containing virtualization extensions (Intel VT or AMD-V).

sect2.title: KVM Prerequisites
sect2.para: Before building qemu, check to see if your processor supports Virtualization Technology (VT):

If you get any output, you have VT technology (vmx for Intel processors and svm for AMD processors). You then need to go into your system BIOS and ensure it is enabled. After enabing, reboot back to your LFS instance.

sect2.title: Kernel Configuration
sect2.para: Enable the following options in the kernel configuration and recompile the kernel if necessary:

screen.literal: [*] Virtualization: ---> [CONFIG_VIRTUALIZATION] <*/M> Kernel-based Virtual Machine (KVM) support [CONFIG_KVM] <*/M> KVM for Intel processors support [CONFIG_KVM_INTEL] <*/M> KVM for AMD processors support [CONFIG_KVM_AMD]

sect2.para: The Intel or AMD settings are not both required, but the one matching your system processor is required.
For networking, check that is installed and the following options in the kernel configuration are enabled:

screen.literal: [*] Networking support ---> [CONFIG_NET] Networking options ---> <*/M> 802.1d Ethernet Bridging [CONFIG_BRIDGE] Device Drivers ---> [*] Network device support ---> [CONFIG_NETDEVICES] <*/M> Universal TUN/TAP device driver support [CONFIG_TUN]

sect2.title: Installation of qemu
sect2.para: Install qemu by running the following commands:

note.para: Qemu is capable of running many targets. The build process is also capable of building multiple targets at one time in a comma delimited list assigned to --target-list. Run ./configure --help to get a complete list of available targets.

screen.userinput:
if [ $(uname -m) = i686 ]; then QEMU_ARCH=i386-softmmu else QEMU_ARCH=x86_64-softmmu fi
mkdir -vp build && cd build &&
../configure --prefix=/usr \ --sysconfdir=/etc \ --target-list=$QEMU_ARCH \ --audio-drv-list=alsa \ --docdir=/usr/share/doc/qemu-&qemu-version; &&
unset QEMU_ARCH &&
make

sect2.para: --audio-drv-list=alsa: This switch sets the audio driver to ALSA. For other drivers see the --audio-drv-list list in configure's help output. The default audio driver is OSS.

note.para: The following instructions assume you have created the optional symbolic link, qemu. Additionally, you must run qemu from an X Window System based terminal (either locally or over ssh).

sect2.para: To install an operating system, download an iso of your choice or use a pre-installed cdrom device. For the purposes of this example, use Fedora 16 that is downloaded as Fedora-16-x86_64-Live-LXDE.iso in the current directory. Run the following:

Follow the normal installation procedures for the chosen distribution. The -boot option specifies the boot order of drives as a string of drive letters. Valid drive letters are: a, b (floppy 1 and 2), c (first hard disk), d (first CD-ROM). The -m option is the amount of memory to use for the virtual machine. If you have sufficient memory (2G or more), 1G is a reasonable value. For computers with 512MB of RAM it's safe to use -m 192, or even -m 128 (the default). The -enable-kvm option allows for hardware acceleration. Without this switch, the emulation is relatively slow.
To run the newly installed operating system, run:

You may have problem with -enable-kvm. Also, you may want to define audio and video drivers, number of cpu cores and threads. An alternative command to install the operating system is (see qemu man page for the parameters definitions):

screen.userinput: qemu -enable-kvm \ -cdrom /home/fernando/ISO/linuxmint-17.1-mate-32bit.iso \ -boot order=d \ -m 1G,slots=3,maxmem=4G \ -machine smm=off \ -soundhw es1370 \ -cpu host \ -smp cores=4,threads=2 \ -vga std \ vdisk.img

sect2.para: One parameter not appearing in the qemu man page is -machine smm=off, and is used to allow -enable-kvm in some systems. In order to run the machine, you can alternatively issue:

screen.userinput: qemu -enable-kvm \ -machine smm=off \ -boot order=d \ -m 1G,slots=3,maxmem=4G \ -soundhw es1370 \ -cpu host \ -smp cores=4,threads=2 \ -vga vmware \ -hda vdisk.img

sect2.para: Sometimes, you want the machine to have different screen sizes than the ones natively offered by the virtual grahics card. The example below is for qemu vmware graphics card, which uses and is set to give maximum screen size of 1600x900. As the root user, issue:

screen.userinput:
cat > /usr/share/X11/xorg.conf.d/20-vmware.conf << "EOF" Section "Monitor" Identifier "Monitor0" # cvt 1600 900 # 1600x900 59.95 Hz (CVT 1.44M9) hsync: 55.99 kHz; pclk: 118.25 MHz Modeline "1600x900" 118.25 1600 1696 1856 2112 900 903 908 934 -hsync +vsync Option "PreferredMode" "1600x900" HorizSync 1-200 VertRefresh 1-200 EndSection
Section "Device" Identifier "VMware SVGA II Adapter" Option "Monitor" "default" Driver "vmware" EndSection
Section "Screen" Identifier "Default Screen" Device "VMware SVGA II Adapter" Monitor "Monitor0"
SubSection "Display" Depth 24 Modes "1600x900" "1440x900" "1366x768" "1280x720" "800x480" EndSubSection
EndSection EOF

sect2.para: New sizes will be available besides the native ones. You need to restart X in order to have the new sizes available.
